tests.name: MJ Academy Practice Test
tests.description: This practice test consists of five sections: an Analytical Writing section, two Quantitative sections, and two Verbal sections

awa.prompt: The luxuries and conveniences of contemporary life prevent people from developing into truly strong and independent individuals.
awa.instructions: Write a response in which you discuss the extent to which you agree or disagree with the statement and explain your reasoning for the position you take. In developing and supporting your position, you should consider ways in which the statement might or might not hold true and explain how these considerations shape your position

question1.questionText: Recent editions of the Chinese classic Tao Te Ching, based on manuscripts more authoritative than those hitherto available, have rendered previous editions _____.

question2.questionText: When the most recent earnings report was delivered at the meeting last week, employees hoped to find indications that their company, having been unprofitable the previous fiscal year, was in a state of (i)__________; however, they were disappointed by the (ii)_______ first quarter earnings.

question3.questionText: The college student’s (i)________ remarks to her professor, made in a brazen and misguided attempt to garner (ii)_________ from her peers, met with unintended consequences when she was banished from the classroom for her (iii)________.

question4.passage: The unequal treaties between Japan and several western powers in the middle of the 19th century proved to be the final straw that broke the back of the Tokugawa Japanese government. Two provinces in particular, Satsuma and Choshu, launched rebellions protesting the Shogunate’s acceptance of the unfavorable terms. Already weakened by an increasingly indebted samurai bureaucracy and faltering political power, the Shogunate was unable to quell the revolution and was forced to capitulate. Guided by ideals of equality among all Japanese, one of the first reforms was the abolition of the class system that was the hallmark of Shogunate rule. Under the Shogunate system, most of Japan’s population was sorted into one of four rigidly defined hereditary classes, with the samurai, or warriors, as the highest, ruling class. Below the samurai ranked the farmers, followed by artisans, followed by the merchants, the lowest caste. In an almost unprecedented move, the leaders of the Satsuma and Choshu rebellions, after reinstating the Emperor to supreme power, renounced their samurai status, opening up the entirety of the Japanese population to military service. Consider each of the choices separately and select all that apply. What can be inferred from the passage? The emperor of Japan had no power under Tokugawa governance. It became possible for Japanese businesspeople to rise in social class after the rebellions in the mid-19th century. Under Tokugawa governance, only samurai were allowed to serve in the military.
question4.questionText: What can be inferred from the passage?
options: The emperor of Japan had no power under Tokugawa governance.
It became possible for Japanese businesspeople to rise in social class after the rebellions in the mid-19th century.
Under Tokugawa governance, only samurai were allowed to serve in the military.
correctAnswer: The emperor of Japan had no power under Tokugawa governance.
It became possible for Japanese businesspeople to rise in social class after the rebellions in the mid-19th century.

question6.questionText: In the passage given, the two highlighted portions play which of the following roles?
question6.passage: To help promote feline health and welfare, an ongoing research project involves identifying genes that control autosomal dominant traits and causative mutations in cats. This study involves understanding the morphological traits that help define different breeds. If researchers can identify {{highlight1}}, they can then determine why only some breeds have health problems connected to the traits. The lack of tails in {{highlight2}} cats is an autosomal dominant trait, for example, and significant problems can arise when a cat has two copies of this mutation. For this reason, the majority of {{highlight2}} cats are bred with cats that have tails.
highlighted: A) the genes that control autosomal dominant traits

question7.questionText: Select the two answer choices that, when used to complete the sentence, fit the meaning of the sentence as a whole and produce completed sentences that are alike in meaning. Since her parents were distracted by their guests after dinner, the child ______ escaped to the kitchen and proceeded to devour all of the remaining cookies.

question8.questionText: Select the two answer choices that, when used to complete the sentence, fit the meaning of the sentence as a whole and produce completed sentences that are alike in meaning. As she stepped down from the podium, the candidate was lauded by an enthusiastic audience of supporters who were gratified not only by the fervency of her delivery but also by the _______ words of her speechwriter.

question9.questionText: Select the two answer choices that, when used to complete the sentence, fit the meaning of the sentence as a whole and produce completed sentences that are alike in meaning. A number of double-blind lab studies have confirmed that soothing activities such as knitting and cooking can counteract the deleterious effects of ________ on the human body.

question10.passage: Phenomenology, an early twentieth-century humanist philosophy inaugurated by Edmund Husserl, is the explicit and rigorous examination and description of consciousness. In the early 1980s, scholars of theater and performance began to employ analysis informed by phenomenology in their writing. These scholars found that phenomenology allowed them to describe their encounters with the performance event in a way unencumbered by the language-centered critical modes of psychoanalysis and deconstruction. Accordingly, phenomenological criticism asserted that a more immediate, visceral experience could be conveyed by suspending the 'haze of secondary associations' that often mediates between the audience and the performance object. Critics of this approach have pointed out that Husserl and other phenomenologists naively thought that language was a transparent system that reflected reality, though this belief has been strongly discredited by linguists and deconstructionist philosophers. This means, they argue, that even if phenomenology gives access to an encounter with the 'essence' of a given art object, this encounter could never be conveyed to others in speech or writing without distortion or filtration of meaning. In response to this criticism, theater and performance scholars have adapted their methodology, citing later phenomenologists like Maurice Merleau-Ponty, whose work focuses on the importance of the body in forming consciousness, and disavowing the reductive formulations of Husserl.
question10.questionText: According to the passage, which of the following is true about the author's opinion on the matter?

question1.questionText: The effect of the wind in the researchers’ results was not__________; on blustery days, the pollution reading rose substantially.

question2.questionText: The startling finding that variations in the rate of the Earth’s rotation depend to an (i)__________degree on the weather has necessitated a complete (ii)__________of the world’s timekeeping methods.

question3.questionText: Ideally, the rules of order of the town meeting would have helped to rein in the (i)__________discussions that deviated from the established meeting agenda. Having been cobbled together over many years and several changes in leadership, the rules, instead of providing (ii)__________governing principles and keeping the meeting on point, actually contained some contradictory information, thus (iii)__________the expected method of discourse at meetings.

question4.questionText: The company claims that the prominent placement it garners on many search engine pages was generated (i)__________. A deeper investigation reveals, however, that some (ii)__________practices were likely employed. The majority of links to the company’s site, the largest contributor to favorable placement, comes from (iii)__________web pages that provide no relevant content.

question5.passage: Although the first major and systematic defense of women’s rights appeared as early as 1792 with Mary Wollstonecraft’s Vindication of the Rights of Woman, it would be almost a century before the theme of women’s equality with men was seriously entertained as a result of John Stuart Mill’s The Subjection of Women (1869). Wollstonecraft argued that women appeared different from men in moral character largely due to the deficient opportunities afforded them and the social expectation that they concern themselves with frivolity. She emphasized the importance of educating women consistent with their role as educators and caretakers of children, yet fell short of clearly defending a statement of the equality of the sexes, sometimes seeming to grant a natural superiority to men. In Mill’s work, the belief that women are by nature inferior to men was subjected to a powerful demand for empirical evidence. Echoing Wollstonecraft, he recognized that women appear inferior due to the differential social constraints acting on the sexes, and insisted that equality must be instituted in practice before women’s nature may be seen clearly enough to allow a fair comparison to men’s. He excoriated the then popular notion that social inequality was needed to safeguard the natural roles of women as caretakers and child bearers. No law, he noted, is needed to prevent women from doing what they naturally cannot but do, and if it is indeed in the best interest of society to have women serve as caretakers, such positions must be made appealing enough to be worth holding.

question7.passage: Dogs are widely used by the police to detect drug smuggling and drug caches. Yet recent evidence suggests that insects might be used more effectively in this capacity. In the 1950s, German biologist Dietrich Schneider developed the first method that enabled researchers to record activity in insect olfactory nerves and to identify the compounds that trigger a behavioral response. Insect olfactory systems are very similar to those of vertebrates. Insects first detect odors via finger-like protuberances on the antenna, called olfactory sensilla. Odorant molecules pass through pores in the outer cuticle of the sensilla and attach to an odorant-binding protein. This protein carries the hydrophobic molecules through the lymph fluid found inside the cell and attaches them to receptors on the dendritic projections of a sensory nerve cell. Finally, these receptors send signals to the central nervous system, allowing for easy detection by researchers. The position of the insect olfactory organs on the surface of its body allows for direct investigation of the system’s response.
question7.questionText: Which of the following best describes the author’s attitude towards the prospect of using insects for drug detection?

question8.questionText: It can be inferred from the passage that insects would be less useful for researchers in detecting drugs if which of the following were true?
options: They were as accurate as, but not more accurate than, dogs in detecting drugs.
Insect olfactory systems did not deliver odorants to nerve cells, as vertebrate olfactory systems do.
Dietrich Schneider did not develop the first method that enabled researchers to record the activity in insect olfactory nerves.
They did not have finger-like protuberances for detecting odors.
The signal sent to the insect’s central nervous system did not allow researchers to identify the compound that triggered the response.
question8.correctAnswer: The signal sent to the insect’s central nervous system did not allow researchers to identify the compound that triggered the response.

question13.passage: Studies have shown that an automobile that runs on a blend of 85% ethanol/15% gasoline gets better mileage than an otherwise similar car equipped with a gasoline engine. Many American legislators have concluded that an increase in tax incentives for ethanol production would lessen our dependence on foreign oil.
question13.questionText: Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt upon the validity of the legislators’ conclusion?
options: It takes 1.5 gallons of oil to produce 1 gallon of ethanol.
Electric cars are cheaper to operate than cars running on the ethanol fuel mix.
It costs thousands of dollars to retrofit an automobile to run on the ethanol fuel mix
The ethanol/gasoline blend emits more pollution that regular gasoline.
The ethanol/gasoline blend has not been widely adopted in Europe.
question13.correctAnswer: It takes 1.5 gallons of oil to produce 1 gallon of ethanol.

question14.passage: Items that seem unremarkable today might once have altered the course of history. For centuries, the nutmeg tree grew only in the Banda Islands. Locals harvested and sold the aromatic nuts of the tree and, eventually, a spice made from these nuts became a luxury item in the European market. Seeking a monopoly over this valuable spice, the Dutch attacked the Bandas, subjugating the native people in a mostly successful attempt to control the trade. However, one island in the Banda chain remained in the hands of the British, engendering much conflict between the Netherlands and England. Finally, the British offered to cede control of the island in exchange for New Amsterdam, a Dutch outpost in North America. The Dutch were more interested in the spice trade than in the small outpost of New Amsterdam. In 1667, the Treaty of Breda gave the Dutch complete control of the Banda Islands, and the nutmeg trade, and gave the British New Amsterdam, promptly renamed New York.
question14.questionText: Which of the following is mentioned in the passage as a reason for the initial interest of the Netherlands in the Banda Islands?
options: An opportunity to expand to a new geographical market
A failure to cultivate nutmeg in other locations
The desire to restrict access to a commodity
question14.correctAnswer: The desire to restrict access to a commodity

tests.name: MJ Academy Practice Test
tests.description: This practice test consists of five sections: an Analytical Writing section, two Quantitative sections, and two Verbal sections

awa.prompt: Some people believe that success in creative fields, such as painting, fiction writing, and filmmaking, primarily requires hard work and perseverance. Others believe that such success mainly requires innate talents that cannot be learned.
awa.instructions: Write a response in which you discuss which view more closely aligns with your own position and explain your reasoning for the position you take. In developing and supporting your position, you should address both of the views presented.

question1.passage: Although custom prosthetic bone replacements produced through a new computer-aided design process will cost more than twice as much as ordinary replacements, custom replacements should still be cost-effective. Not only will surgery and recovery time be reduced, but custom replacements should last longer, thereby reducing the need for further hospital stays.
question1.questionText: Which of the following must be studied in order to evaluate the argument presented above?
options: The amount of time a patient spends in surgery versus the amount of time spent recovering from surgery
The amount by which the cost of producing custom replacements has declined with the introduction of the new technique for producing them
The degree to which the use of custom replacements is likely to reduce the need for repeat surgery when compared with the use of ordinary replacements
The degree to which custom replacements produced with the new technique are more carefully manufactured than are ordinary replacements
The amount by which custom replacements produced with the new technique will drop in cost as the production procedures become standardized and applicable on a larger scale
correctAnswer: The degree to which the use of custom replacements is likely to reduce the need for repeat surgery when compared with the use of ordinary replacements
question1.explanation: Although costly to produce, custom bone replacements are tentatively projected to be cost-effective because of other savings. To evaluate the argument it must be determined whether these savings will compensate for the increased cost. Thus, study of the expected reduction in the need for further hospital stays is needed, and choice C is the best answer. The argument requires no study of the ratio between surgery and recovery time, so choice A is inappropriate. Past and future changes in cost are irrelevant to evaluating an argument that is based on the currently projected cost, so choices B and E are inappropriate. Finally, since studying the care with which the custom replacements are made does not itself provide information about costs, choice D is also incorrect.

question2.questionText: Even those who disagreed with Carmen's views rarely faulted her for expressing them, for the positions she took were as _____ as they were controversial.
question2.explanation: The sentence indicates that people disagreed with Carmen’s views as the positions she took were controversial but rarely found defects with her views as they were carefully thought about before she expressed them. Thus, Carmen’s views were 'thoughtful' and 'considered'.

question3.questionText: New research on technology and public policy focuses on how seemingly insignificant design features, generally overlooked in most analyses of public works projects or industrial machinery, actually _____ social choices of profound significance.
question3.explanation: The word 'actually' indicates that in reality the design features which appear to be insignificant and are neglected, are not irrelevant but hide social choices of profound significance. The words closest in meaning to the word 'hide' are mask and cloak.

question4.questionText: Paradoxically, Robinson's excessive denials of the worth of early works of science fiction suggest that she has become quite ______ them.
question4.explanation: The word paradoxically indicates that there should be a contradiction in Robinson's refusal to accept the worth of early works of science fiction as instead of denying their existence, she was fascinated by them. The contradictory fascination is related by the words 'enamored of' and 'infatuated with'.

question5.questionText: Cezanne's delicate watercolor sketches often served as ______ of a subject, a way of gathering fuller knowledge before the artist's final engagement of the subject in an oil painting.
question5.explanation: The sentence states that Cezanne's watercolor sketches were a way of gathering fuller knowledge, which means that they helped in observation and seeking out information of a subject. Thus, watercolor sketches served as a reconnaissance and a surveillance.

question6.passage: During the Second World War, about 375,000 civilians died in the United States and about 408,000 members of the United States armed forces died overseas. On the basis of those figures, it can be concluded that it was not much more dangerous to be overseas in the armed forces during the Second World War than it was to stay at home as a civilian.
question6.questionText: Which of the following would reveal most clearly the absurdity of the conclusion drawn above?
options: Counting deaths among members of the armed forces who served in the United State in addition to deaths among members of the armed forces serving overseas
Expressing the difference between the numbers of deaths among civilians and members of the armed forces as a percentage of the total number of deaths
Separating deaths caused by accidents during service in the armed forces from deaths caused by combat injuries
Comparing death rates per thousand members of each group rather than comparing total numbers of deaths
Comparing deaths caused by accidents in the United States to deaths caused by combat in the armed forces
correctAnswer: Comparing death rates per thousand members of each group rather than comparing total numbers of deaths
question6.explanation: Concluding from the similar numbers of deaths in two groups that the relative danger of death was similar for both groups is absurd if, as here, one group was far smaller. D exposes this absurdity by pointing out the need to compare death rates of the two groups, which would reveal the higher death rate for the smaller group. Therefore, D is the best answer. Since the conclusion acknowledges the difference between the number of civilian and armed forces deaths, expressing this difference as a percentage, as suggested by B, is beside the point. A is inappropriate because it simply adds a third group to the two being compared. Because cause of death is not at issue, C and E are irrelevant.

question7.questionText: Externally the jollity of old men has much in common with the mirth of children; the intellect, any more than a deep sense of humor, has little to do with this matter as it is. In both cases it is a gleam that plays upon the (i) ______ and imparts a sunny, cheery aspect alike to green branch and grey moldering trunk. In one case however it is real (ii) ______ and in the other it is the (iii) ______ of decaying wood.
question7.explanation: The passage has imagery of light and compares the jollity of old men with the mirth of children. Blank 1 can be completed logically with 'surface,' blank 2 with 'sunshine,' and in the final blank, the word is 'radiant glow' in keeping with the imagery of light.

question8.questionText: Religious philosopher that he was, Henry More derived his conception of an infinite universe from the Infinite God in whom he believed; a benevolent God of (i) _______ whose nature was to create (ii) _______.
question8.explanation: The key to this one lies in 'benevolent God.' Since the god is benevolent and there is no specific appositional phrase after the ';', we assume it's a support sign and therefore the missing blank has to be a positive word. Therefore, 'plenitude,' which is the only positive word, is the answer. The second blank is dependent on the first and so 'abundance' will be the answer. They are synonyms after all.

question9.questionText: The author did not see the _______ inherent in her scathing criticism of a writing style so similar to her own.
question9.explanation: The first part - 'The author did not see' brings out the discrepancy in 'scathing criticism of a writing style so similar to her own.' She is criticizing a writing style which is similar to her own which is pretty weird. Therefore look for a similar word. In this case it is 'incongruity.'

question10.passage: Toughened hiring standards have not been the primary cause of the present staffing shortage in public schools. The shortage of teachers is primarily caused by the fact that in recent years teachers have not experienced any improvements in working conditions and their salaries have not kept pace with salaries in other professions.
question10.questionText: Which of the following, if true, would most support the claims above?
options: Many teachers already in the profession would not have been hired under the new hiring standards.
Today more teachers are entering the profession with a higher educational level than in the past.
Some teachers have cited higher standards for hiring as a reason for the current staffing shortage.
Many teachers have cited low pay and lack of professional freedom as reasons for their leaving the profession.
Many prospective teachers have cited the new hiring standards as a reason for not entering the profession.
correctAnswer: Many teachers have cited low pay and lack of professional freedom as reasons for their leaving the profession.
question10.explanation: The passage rejects one explanation of the shortage of teachers—that it results from toughened hiring standards—and advances an alternative—that it results from deficiencies in pay and working conditions. D provides corroborative evidence for the latter explanation by suggesting that, for many former teachers, poor pay and working conditions were reasons for their quitting the profession. Therefore, D is the best answer. A, C, and E provide evidence that tends to implicate new hiring standards in the staffing shortage and thus support the explanation that the passage rejects. B describes what may be a result of the new hiring standards, but it provides no evidence favoring one explanation of the staffing shortage over the other.

question11.passage: It is now established that the Milky Way is far more extended and of much greater mass than was hitherto thought. However, all that is visible of the constituents of the Milky Way's corona (outer edge), where much of the galaxy's mass must be located, is a tiny fraction of the corona's mass. Thus, most of the Milky Way's outlying matter must be dark. Why? Three facts are salient. First, dwarf galaxies and globular clusters, into which most of the stars of the Milky Way's corona are probably bound, consist mainly of old stars. Second, old stars are not highly luminous. Third, no one has detected in the corona the clouds of gaseous matter such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide that are characteristic of the bright parts of a galaxy. At present, therefore, the best explanation—though still quite tentative—for the darkness of the corona is that the corona is composed mainly of old burned-out stars.
question11.questionText: According to the passage, a bright part of a galaxy typically includes
options: gases such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide.
a balanced mixture of old and new stars.
a large portion of the galaxy's mass.
correctAnswer: gases such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide.
question11.explanation: As suggested by the passage, the bright parts of the galaxy consist of clouds made up of gases such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide. Thus, it can be concluded that these gases are bright, which constitute a bright part of the galaxy, giving option (A) as the correct answer. Option (B) is incorrect because a bright part of the galaxy cannot have an equal number of old and new stars as old stars are not very luminous (throwing away light) and their presence will not make the galaxy bright but dark. Option (C) is incorrect because the outer edge of the Milky Way called corona is where the galaxy's major mass is located. Due to the maximum amount of mass present in the outer edge, it is dark.

question12.passage: It is now established that the Milky Way is far more extended and of much greater mass than was hitherto thought. However, all that is visible of the constituents of the Milky Way's corona (outer edge), where much of the galaxy's mass must be located, is a tiny fraction of the corona's mass. Thus, most of the Milky Way's outlying matter must be dark. Why? Three facts are salient. First, dwarf galaxies and globular clusters, into which most of the stars of the Milky Way's corona are probably bound, consist mainly of old stars. Second, old stars are not highly luminous. Third, no one has detected in the corona the clouds of gaseous matter such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide that are characteristic of the bright parts of a galaxy. At present, therefore, the best explanation though still quite tentative for the darkness of the corona is that the corona is composed mainly of old burned-out stars.
question12.questionText: Select the sentence in the passage which implies that, until fairly recently, astronomers believed that the Milky Way was much smaller.
correctAnswer: It is now established that the Milky Way is far more extended and of much greater mass than was hitherto thought
question12.explanation: The above-mentioned sentence from the passage applies to the given statement because the sentence shows that in recent years there has been a new discovery about the expanse and weight of the Milky Way which is much greater than what was earlier believed by the astronomers.

question1.passage: Airline: Newly developed collision-avoidance systems, although not fully tested to discover potential malfunctions, must be installed immediately in passenger planes. Their mechanical warnings enable pilots to avoid crashes. Pilots: Pilots will not fly in planes with collision-avoidance systems that are not fully tested. Malfunctioning systems could mislead pilots, causing crashes.
question1.questionText: The pilots’ objection is most strengthened if which of the following is true?
options: It is always possible for mechanical devices to malfunction.
Jet engines, although not fully tested when first put into use, have achieved exemplary performance and safety records.
Although collision-avoidance systems will enable pilots to avoid some crashes, the likely malfunctions of the not-fully-tested systems will cause even more crashes.
Many airline collisions are caused in part by the exhaustion of overworked pilots.
Collision-avoidance systems, at this stage of development, appear to have worked better in passenger planes than in cargo planes during experimental flights made over a six-month period.
correctAnswer: Although collision-avoidance systems will enable pilots to avoid some crashes, the likely malfunctions of the not-fully-tested systems will cause even more crashes.
question1.explanation: Choice C states that what the pilots think could happen is likely to happen. Thus, C is the best choice. Choice A is inappropriate because it says nothing about the malfunctions that most concern the pilots—those that might mislead. Nor does A distinguish tested from not-fully-tested systems. Choice B is inappropriate. The only outcome of using insufficiently tested equipment that might strengthen the pilots' objection is an unfavorable one, but B reports on a favorable outcome. Choice D is inappropriate because it mentions a problem that needs to be addressed whether or not the collision-avoidance systems are installed immediately. Choice E is inappropriate because it provides no evidence that any malfunctions were of a sort to mislead pilots and cause crashes.

question2.passage: The deep sea typically has a sparse fauna dominated by tiny worms and crustaceans, with an even sparser distribution of larger animals. However, near hydrothermal vents, areas of the ocean where warm water emerges from subterranean sources, live remarkable densities of huge clams, blind crabs, and fish. Most deep-sea faunas rely for food on particulate matter, ultimately derived from photosynthesis, falling from above. The food supplies necessary to sustain the large vent communities, however, must be many times the ordinary fallout. The first reports describing vent faunas proposed two possible sources of nutrition: bacterial chemosynthesis, production of food by bacteria using energy derived from chemical changes, and advection, the drifting of food materials from surrounding regions. Later, evidence in support of the idea of intense local chemosynthesis was accumulated: hydrogen sulfide was found in vent water; many vent-site bacteria were found to be capable of chemosynthesis; and extremely large concentrations of bacteria were found in samples of vent water thought to be pure. This final observation seemed decisive. If such astonishing concentrations of bacteria were typical of vent outflow, then food within the vent would dwarf any contribution from advection. Hence, the widely quoted conclusion was reached that bacterial chemosynthesis provides the foundation for hydrothermal-vent food chains—an exciting prospect because no other communities on Earth are independent of photosynthesis.
question2.questionText: Select the sentence in the passage which implies that the majority of deep-sea faunas that live in nonvent habitats are smaller than many vent faunas.
correctAnswer: The deep sea typically has a sparse fauna dominated by tiny worms and crustaceans, with an even sparser distribution of larger animals
question2.explanation: As suggested by the statement deep sea has a fauna which is scattered and very less density of the species of the organisms are found there. These regions have a less density of tiny worms and crustaceans which dominate these regions and even lesser number of species of larger animals. Thus, faunas found in the deep sea region are smaller when compared to the other vent faunas.

question3.passage: The deep sea typically has a sparse fauna dominated by tiny worms and crustaceans, with an even sparser distribution of larger animals. However, near hydrothermal vents, areas of the ocean where warm water emerges from subterranean sources, live remarkable densities of huge clams, blind crabs, and fish. Most deep-sea faunas rely for food on particulate matter, ultimately derived from photosynthesis, falling from above. The food supplies necessary to sustain the large vent communities, however, must be many times the ordinary fallout. Later, evidence in support of the idea of intense local chemosynthesis was accumulated: hydrogen sulfide was found in vent water; many vent-site bacteria were found to be capable of chemosynthesis; and extremely large concentrations of bacteria were found in samples of vent water thought to be pure. This final observation seemed decisive. If such astonishing concentrations of bacteria were typical of vent outflow, then food within the vent would dwarf any contribution from advection. Hence, the widely quoted conclusion was reached that bacterial chemosynthesis provides the foundation for hydrothermal-vent food chains—an exciting prospect because no other communities on Earth are independent of photosynthesis.
question3.questionText: Which of the following is information supplied in the passage that would support the statement that the food supplies necessary to sustain vent communities must be many times that of ordinary fallout?
options: Large vent faunas move from vent to vent in search of food.
Vent faunas are not able to consume food produced by photosynthesis.
Vents are more densely populated than are other deep-sea areas.
correctAnswer: Vents are more densely populated than are other deep-sea areas.
question3.explanation: The passage shows that vents are the regions inside the ocean where large densities of organisms like clams, blind crabs, and fishes are found and this stands in contrast to the number of organisms living in the deep sea, which is very less. Since the number of organisms living in the deep sea is less, they can survive on the particulate food matter falling from the above regions of the sea but the large amount of organisms in the vent area require huge quantities of food when compared to the former. Thus, option (C) is the correct answer.

question4.questionText: Our biological uniqueness requires that the effects of substance must be verified by _______ experiments, even after thousands of tests of the effects of that substance on animals.
question4.explanation: The answer lies in 'Our biological uniqueness requires' + 'even after thousands of tests of the effects of that substance on animals.' Since we are biologically unique from other animals, the results, even after countless experiments on animals, may not apply to us. So we need to test it on 'humans' as well. That's the answer.

question5.questionText: Our highly (i) _______ vocabulary for street crime contrasts sharply with our (ii) _______ vocabulary for corporate crime, a fact that corresponds to the general public's unawareness of the extent of corporate crime.
question5.explanation: The key to the first blank lies in 'contrasts sharply with our,' implying the difference in vocabulary. Hence 'differentiated' is the answer. For the second blank, the key lies in 'that corresponds to the general public's unawareness to the extent.' It is actually an appositional phrase supported by 'corresponds.' Hence the answer is 'limited.'

question6.questionText: When a person suddenly loses consciousness, a bystander is not expected to (i) _______ the problem but to attempt to (ii) _______ its effects by starting vital functions if they are absent.
question6.explanation: Let's take the first blank first. A bystander cannot be expected to 'diagnose' the problem but the other two are quite possible depending on the bystander's mental ineptitude. So 'diagnose' is the answer. For the second blank, 'evaluate' cannot be an option because, as we discussed earlier, he is also not expected to 'predict' its effects by starting vital functions, if they are absent. So 'counter' is the only option.

question7.questionText: Middlemarch is a difficult novel to discuss. Just as the insensitive Jane Austen reader complains “nothing happens,” so too some readers call Middlemarch a (i) _______ novel, with tiresome repetition. Such readers are the (ii) _______ readers who look for (iii) _______ gratification.
question7.explanation: The passage describes the novel 'Middlemarch' as one in which readers complain 'nothing happens,' so the word in the first blank is 'monochromatic.' Then it is said that this novel is boring 'only to the casual reader' who looks for 'presto' or an 'instant gratification.' It is implied that the novel is not as boring as it seems to be.

question8.passage: The more that is discovered about the intricate organization of the nervous system, the more it seems remarkable that genes can successfully specify the development of that system. Human genes contain too little information even to specify which hemisphere of the brain each of a human’s 10^11 neurons should occupy, let alone the hundreds of connections that each neuron makes. For such reasons, we can assume that there must be an important random factor in neural development, and in particular, that errors must and do occur in the development of all normal brains.
question8.questionText: According to the passage, one of the reasons it has been assumed that there is an important random element in human neural development is that
options: genes cannot specify certain types of developmental processes as well as they can others
the intricacy of the nervous system allows small developmental errors to occur without harmful effects
the amount of information contained in the genes is less than the amount necessary to specify the location of the neurons
the number of neurons in the human brain varies greatly from individual to individual
it is theoretically impossible for an organism to protect itself completely from gross developmental mistakes
correctAnswer: the amount of information contained in the genes is less than the amount necessary to specify the location of the neurons
question8.explanation: According to the passage, it has been assumed that there is an important random element in human neural development because genes can specify the development of an intricate nervous system and contain even the minutest of the information to specify the location as to which hemisphere of the brain each of a human's 10^11 neurons should occupy.

question9.passage: Ragtime is a musical form that synthesizes folk melodies and musical techniques into a brief quadrille-like structure, designed to be played—exactly as written—on the piano. A strong analogy exists between European composers like Ralph Vaughan Williams, Edvard Grieg, and Anton Dvorak who combined folk tunes and their own original materials in larger compositions and the pioneer ragtime composers in the United States. Composers like Scott Joplin and James Scott were in a sense collectors or musicologists, collecting dance and folk music in Black communities and consciously shaping it into brief suites or anthologies called piano rags.
question9.questionText: According to the passage, Ralph Vaughan Williams, Anton Dvorak, and Scott Joplin are similar in that they all
options: wrote original compositions based on folk tunes
collected and recorded abbreviated piano suites
explored the relations between Black music and continental folk music
correctAnswer: wrote original compositions based on folk tunes
question9.explanation: According to the passage, Ralph Vaughan Williams, Anton Dvorak, and Scott Joplin are similar because they combined folk tunes and their original compositions. However, they all borrowed from folk tunes, their composition material was original. Thus, option (A) is the correct answer. Option (B) is incorrect because it was not the above-mentioned three musicians who collected and recorded abbreviated piano suites but Scott Joplin and James Scott who did that. Option (C) is incorrect because it was Scott Joplin and James Scott who explored the relations between Black music and continental folk music and not the above-mentioned people.

question10.passage: The determination of the sources of copper ore used in the manufacture of copper and bronze artifacts of Bronze Age civilizations would add greatly to our knowledge of cultural contacts and trade in that era. Researchers have analyzed artifacts and ores for their concentrations of elements, but for a variety of reasons, these studies have generally failed to provide evidence of the sources of the copper used in the objects. Elemental composition can vary within the same copper-ore lode, usually because of varying admixtures of other elements, especially iron, lead, zinc, and arsenic. And high concentrations of cobalt or zinc, noticed in some artifacts, appear in a variety of copper-ore sources. Moreover, the processing of ores introduced poorly controlled changes in the concentrations of minor and trace elements in the resulting metal. Some elements evaporate during smelting and roasting; different temperatures and processes produce different degrees of loss. Finally, flux, which is sometimes added during smelting to remove waste material from the ore, could add quantities of elements to the final product.
question10.questionText: According to the passage, possible sources of the lead found in a copper or bronze artifact include which of the following?
options: The copper ore used to manufacture the artifact
Flux added during processing of the copper ore
Other metal added during processing of the copper ore
correctAnswer: The copper ore used to manufacture the artifact
Flux added during processing of the copper ore
Other metal added during processing of the copper ore
question10.explanation: According to the passage, one of the sources of lead which is found in the artifacts made of copper or bronze is the copper ore which contains lead in its impure state. Copper ore is processed to extract the pure form of copper devoid of all the impurities which are present in its ore. However, sometimes lead which is present in the ore as an impurity does not separate from the ore after processing and remains a part of the metal. The artifacts made up of this copper definitely have the presence of lead. Thus, option (A) applies to the answer. Flux is a substance which is added during the smelting of the copper ore to remove impurities from the ore and is a part of the process of processing of the ore to derive a pure form of copper. The adding of flux sometimes has its own disadvantages because instead of removing impurities during the process of smelting it could add impurities to copper. Lead could be one of the impurities added to copper by flux and find space in the final product. This copper with lead concentration when used to make artifacts has lead in them. Thus, option (B) applies to the answer. Other metal added during the processing of the copper ore could have some amount of lead in it which would lead to the presence of lead in the final pure copper. Thus, artifacts made up of this copper will have lead in them. Thus, option (C) applies to the answer.

question11.passage: Extraordinary creative activity has been characterized as revolutionary, flying in the face of what is established and producing not what is acceptable but what will become accepted. According to this formulation, highly creative activity transcends the limits of an existing form and establishes a new principle of organization. However, the idea that extraordinary creativity transcends established limits is misleading when it is applied to the arts, even though it may be valid for the sciences. Differences between highly creative art and highly creative science arise in part from a difference in their goals. For the sciences, a new theory is the goal and end result of the creative act. Innovative science produces new propositions in terms of which diverse phenomena can be related to one another in more coherent ways. Such phenomena as a brilliant diamond or a nesting bird are relegated to the role of data, serving as the means for formulating or testing a new theory. The goal of highly creative art is very different: the phenomenon itself becomes the direct product of the creative act. Shakespeare's Hamlet is not a tract about the behavior of indecisive princes or the uses of political power; nor is Picasso's painting Guernica primarily a propositional statement about the Spanish Civil War or the evils of fascism. What highly creative artistic activity produces is not a new generalization that transcends established limits, but rather an aesthetic particular. Aesthetic particulars produced by the highly creative artist extend or exploit, in an innovative way, the limits of an existing form, rather than transcend that form.
question11.questionText: The author considers a new theory that coherently relates diverse phenomena to one another to be the
options: result of highly creative scientific activity
synthesis underlying a great work of art
correctAnswer: result of highly creative scientific activity
question11.explanation: According to the passage, sciences produce new propositions by which different phenomena can be related to one another. The passage gives an example that phenomena like a brilliant diamond or a nesting bird are used as data for the formulation or testing of a new theory. Thus, the phenomena lead to a final end result, establishing a relationship between it and the goal achieved. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer.

question12.questionText: The author implies that an innovative scientific contribution is one that
options: does not relegate particulars to the role of data
presents the discovery of a new scientific fact
question12.explanation: The author in the passage states that innovative science produces new propositions by which different phenomena can be related for the formation and testing of a new theory, thus producing a general idea obtained by relating together two diverse phenomena. Thus, option (B) is the correct answer.

question13.questionText: Aspartame, a new artificial sugar substitute, is only a partial replacement for saccharin because, unlike saccharin, it breaks down and loses its sweetening characteristics at high temperatures, making it _____ for baking.
question13.explanation: The phrase 'partial replacement' suggests that Aspartame cannot be used like saccharin completely because it does not function like saccharin at high temperatures. Baking is a process that requires a high temperature, and Aspartame loses its sweetening on excessive heating, making the baked product devoid of sweetness. This shows that Aspartame is 'unsuitable' and 'inappropriate' for baking.

question14.questionText: Trapped thousands of years ago in Antarctic ice, recently discovered air bubbles are _____ time capsules filled with information for scientists who chart the history of the atmosphere.
question14.explanation: The air bubbles provide true information about the atmospheric conditions present thousands of years ago as they were trapped in ice at the same time and consist of the same air that was present in the atmosphere at that time. These air bubbles are used for actual information by the scientists who map the history of the atmosphere. The air bubbles are hence true time capsules. The words closest in meaning to true are veritable and utter.

question15.questionText: Although often extremely critical of the medical profession as a whole, people are rarely willing to treat their personal doctors with equal _____.
question15.explanation: The word 'although' indicates that the two parts of the sentence are in opposition to each other. The sentence suggests that although people find fault (critical) with the medical profession, in actuality, they do not do so with their personal doctors and therefore do not dislike them. The words which closely describe 'dislike' are 'hatred' and 'contempt.'

question1.questionText: Column A: The distance a car travels in 60 minutes at 30 mph. Column B: The distance a car travels in 30 minutes at 60 mph.
question1.quantityA: The distance a car travels in 60 minutes at 30 mph
question1.quantityB: The distance a car travels in 30 minutes at 60 mph
options: Relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question1.explanation:
Distance = speed * time

Col A: 
Time = 60 min = 1 hr
Distance = 1 hour * 30 mph = 30 miles

Col B: 
Time = 30 min = 1/2 hr
Distance = 1/2 * 60 mph = 30 miles

So the answer is C

question2.questionText: What is the sum of all integers x, such that -37 <= x <= 35?
question2.explanation:
As -37 <= x <= 35, the sum is calculated as follows:
Sum = -37 + (-36) + (-35) + ... + 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + ... + 35

-1 gets canceled with 1
-2 gets canceled with 2
Similarly, up to -35, all negative numbers are canceled with positive numbers until 35.
Sum = (-37) + (-36) = -73

question3.questionText: A bus trip of 450 miles would have taken 1 hour less if the average speed S for the trip had been greater by 5 miles per hour. What was the average speed S, in miles per hour, for the trip?
question3.explanation: Satisfy the equation with options (Best Method)

question4.questionText: If 7 workers can build 7 cars in 7 days, then how many days would it take 5 workers to build 5 cars?
question4.explanation:
If 7 workers build 7 cars in 7 days:
As the number of workers decreases, the days will increase proportionally, but if the number of cars decreases, the days will decrease proportionally.

- 1 worker can build 7 cars in (7 X 7) days
- 1 worker can build 1 car in (7 X 7)/7 days = 7 days

Now, doing the reverse job to find the answer:
1 worker can build 5 cars in 7 X 5 days
But 5 workers can build 5 cars in (7X5)/5 days = 7 days

question5.questionText: In △ABC, ∠A = 40°. D is a point on AC, such that BD = BC. If ∠ABD = 30°, find ∠ABC?
question5.explanation:
Given: ∠A = 40° and ∠ABD = 30°

Now, in a triangle, the sum of angles = 180°.

∠ADB = 180° - 40° - 30° = 110°.

Hence, ∠BDC = 180° - 110° = 70° (Linear pair).

Now as BD = BC,

∠BDC = ∠BCD = 70°.

Hence, in triangle BDC:
∠CBD = 180° - 70° - 70° = 40°.

Therefore, ∠ABC = 40° + 30° = 70°.

question6.questionText: Marge has n candies, where n is an integer such that 20 < n < 50. If Marge divides the candies equally among 5 children, she will have 2 candies remaining. If she divides the candies among 6 children, she will have 1 candy remaining. How many candies will remain if she divides the candies among 7 children?
question6.explanation:
Given: 20 < n < 50

Let the number of candies distributed to each child when there are 5 children = x

And, when there are 6 children = y

Now, x = 5x + 2 = 6y + 1 .........1st equation

Also, as x < 50, x = y + 1 .................2nd equation

Solving equations 1 and 2, we get n = 37

Hence, the answer is 2

question7.questionText:
a, b, c, and d are positive. 

Given: 

a/2 + b/6 = c/3 + d/9
options: The Relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question7.explanation:
Given: 

a/2 + b/6 = c/3 + d/9

Multiply both sides by 18:

 9a + 3b = 6c + 2d

As d is positive, the answer is that Quantity B is greater.

question8.questionText: Choose from the most suitable option below.
options: The Relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question8.explanation:
Column A: 
√(33/175) = √0.2

Column B: 
√(10/6) = √1.66

Obviously, B > A (as B > 1 & A < 1)

question9.questionText: There are more boys in each class than girls. There are 40 students in Class A and 30 students in Class B.
question9.quantityA: Number of boys in Class A
question9.quantityB: Number of boys in Class B
options: The relationship cannot be determined from the information given
question9.correctAnswer: The relationship cannot be determined from the information given
question9.explanation:
Class A (40 students): Boys > Girls
Class B (30 students): Boys > Girls

For Class A: 21 <= Boys <= 40
For Class B: 16 <= Boys <= 30

Case I: If Boys in A = 21 and Boys in B = 16, then A > B.
Case II: If Boys in A = 21 and Boys in B = 26, then A < B.

Thus, the relationship cannot be determined by the given information.

question10.questionText: The sum of the first 20 positive even integers is...
question10.explanation:
Sum1 = 2 + 4 + 6 + 8 + 10 + ... + 40

= 2 * (1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + ... + 20)

The sum of the first n natural numbers is given by the formula: n(n + 1) / 2.

Hence, Sum1 = 2 * 20(20 + 1) / 2 = 420.

Note: The sum of the first n even numbers is n(n + 1), and the sum of the first n odd numbers is n^2.

question12.questionText: A certain grocery purchased x pounds of produce for p dollars per pound. If y pounds of the produce had to be discarded due to spoilage and the grocery sold the rest for s dollars per pound, which of the following represents the gross profit on the sale of the produce?
question12.explanation:
Cost price = x * p dollars
Selling price = (x - y) * s dollars
Profit = (x - y) * s - xp

question1.questionText: The figures show (i)SALES and (ii)EARNINGS of a consolidated conglomerate(in million dollars). During which year was the company’s earnings is 10 percent of its sales?
question1.explanation:
During 85th year 
Sales = 8
Earnings = 80
As 8 is 10% of 80, correct answer is 85.

question2.questionText: During the years 1986 through 1988, what are the average earnings per year?
question2.explanation:
1986 = 5 million
1987 = 10 million
1988 = 12 million

Total = 27 (5 + 10 + 12)

Average = 27 / 3 = 9 million dollars.

question4.questionText: What percent of 15 is 15 percent of 1?

question5.questionText: If a, b, and c are three different positive integers each less than 15, what is the greatest possible value for the expression (ab)/c?
question5.explanation:
Given 0 < a, b, c < 15
Let a & b be the largest, i.e., 14 & 13, and c be the smallest, i.e., 1.

(a * b)/c = (14 * 13)/1 = 182

question6.questionText: Running at the same constant rate, 6 identical machines can produce a total of 270 bottles per minute. At this rate, how many bottles could 10 such machines produce in 4 minutes?
question6.explanation:
6 machines = 270 bottles/minute
1 machine = 270/6 = 45 bottles/minute
10 machines = 45 * 10 = 450 bottles/minute
So, 450 * 4 = 1,800 bottles in 4 minutes.

question7.questionText: If x is an integer, and k = (x - 1)(x + 2) - (x - 1)(x - 2), then which of the following must be true?
options: k is odd only when x is odd.
k is odd only when x is even.
k is even only when x is even.
k is even only when x is odd.
question7.explanation:
k = (x - 1)(x + 2) - (x - 1)(x - 2)

= (x^2 + x - 2) - (x^2 - 3x + 2)

= 4x - 4

= 4(x - 1)

k is always even. Hence, the answer is the 5th option.

question8.questionText: If n is an odd integer, which one of the following is an even integer?
question8.explanation:
n = odd

1) (n)^3 = odd
2) n/4 = Fraction
3) 2n+3 = odd
4) n(n+3) = odd * (odd + 3) = odd * even = even
5) √n = Real number or odd

Hence, the answer is the 4th option.

question9.correctAnswer: The relationship cannot be determined from the information given
question9.explanation:
|x| > 1 implies x < -1 or x > 1.

Case 1 (x < -1):
x = -2
x^2 = 4, x^3 = -8

Case 2 (x > 1):
x = 2
x^2 = 4, x^3 = 8

Thus, the relationship cannot be determined.

question10.questionText: Given 0 < x < 1, compare the following quantities:
options: The relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question10.explanation:
If 0 < x < 1:
Let x = 1/64

A = ∛(1/64) = 1/4
B = √(1/64) = 1/8

Therefore, A > B.
Answer = Option 1

question11.questionText: Line segments AB and CD are chords of circle O.
question11.quantityB: The length of AB plus twice the length of CD
options: The relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question11.explanation:
As the largest chord can be the diameter:

Suppose both AB & CD are diameters (d):

A = Circumference = πd = 3.14d
B = Sum = d + 2d = 3d

Hence, A > B.

Answer = Option 1

question12.questionText: A rectangular box has sides a, b, c, and its diagonal is d. If X = √(a² + b² + c²), which of the following is also equal to x?
question12.explanation: Length of diagonal of cuboid = √(l² + b² + h²) = √(a² + b² + c²) = X. Therefore, the answer is the 5th option.

question13.questionText: On the xy-plane, what is the slope of a line that is perpendicular to the line defined by the equation 3y = (1/2)x + 3?
question13.explanation:
Equation: x/2 - 3y + 3 = 0.

Slope = -A/B = (-1/2) / -3 = 1/6.

If perpendicular, slope1 x slope2 = -1.

Therefore, slope2 = -6.

Hence, the answer is option 1.

question14.questionText: Fifteen boys, numbered 1 to 15, are positioned equidistantly along a straight path for a sailboat race. The race begins at boy 1, and 3/4 hours into the race the fastest boat reaches boy 10. At the same average speed, how many minutes will it take the boat to race from boy 10 to boy 15?
question14.explanation:
Boy 1 to boy 10 takes 3/4 hours.
Let the distance between 2 boys be x.
Therefore, it takes 3/4 hours for 9x.
Hence, for 5x, the time is 25/60 = 25 minutes.

question15.quantityB: Two times the 24th term of Set S
options: Relationship cannot be determined by the given information
question15.explanation:
A = 25n + 25
B = (24n + 23) * 2
Hence, B > A.
Answer is Option 2.

tests.name: MJ Academy Practice Test
tests.description: This practice test consists of five sections: an Analytical Writing section, two Quantitative sections, and two Verbal sections

awa.prompt: In most professions and academic fields, imagination is more important than knowledge.
awa.instructions: Write a response in which you discuss the extent to which you agree or disagree with the statement and explain your reasoning for the position you take. In developing and supporting your position, you should consider ways in which the statement might or might not hold true and explain how these considerations shape your position.

question1.questionText: Aalto, like other modernists, believed that form follows function; consequently, his furniture designs asserted the ______ of human needs, and the furniture’s form was determined by human use.
question1.explanation: The word "consequently" indicates that the furniture designs of Aalto are the result of his belief, in which function is given the first preference, followed by the form. As a result, the function of his designs focused on human needs and placed them first in rank, followed by the form, which was determined by the use by humans. Thus, having placed the needs before use, Aalto asserted the "primacy" of human need.

question2.questionText: We understand pain as a sensation, we understand winter through cold. We have to hoist ourselves out of the fundamental and (i) _______ construct of our minds to experience realities that are (ii) _______. It is only when we rise above this (iii) _______ that we can sense true spiritual consciousness.
question2.explanation: The essence of this passage is this: we need to broaden our horizon to understand realities. Hence the word in blank 1 has to be 'circumscribing.' Also, there is a sense that this is critical for understanding 'non-sensory' realities, and for the last blank, the word is 'paradigm.'

question3.questionText: The remark was only slightly (i) ______, inviting a chuckle, perhaps, but certainly not a (ii) ______.
question3.explanation: Since the remark invites chuckles, it can't be either 'audible' or 'coherent' but 'amusing.' However, since it is only slightly amusing, it invites only a chuckle. Now, since we have the contrast sign 'but,' we are looking for an antonym to chuckle, which is 'guffaw.'

question4.questionText: A/an _____ acceptance of contemporary forms of social behavior has misled a few into believing that values in conflict with the present age are for all practical purposes superseded.
question4.explanation: The word misled suggests that a few people, who believe that values which are in opposition with those of the present age are discarded (superseded), do not have a correct belief and this belief has been made possible by the acceptance of the present (contemporary) values without protest. Thus, the acceptance of the values is 'complacent' and 'acquiescent.'

question5.questionText: After thirty years of television, people have become 'speed watchers'; consequently, if the camera lingers, the interest of the audience ______.
question5.explanation: The word 'consequently' indicates that as a result of a long history of watching television, people have become used to and developed interest in watching things in rapid action. If something happens contrary to this, such as the slow movement of things, their interest decreases, and they get bored. The words which best describe the interest of the audience after watching slow actions are 'palls' and 'flags.'

question6.questionText: Compared mathematically to smoking and driving, almost everything else seems relatively risk-free, ___ almost nothing seems worth regulating.
question6.explanation: The sentence indicates that other things seem comparatively (relatively) free of danger when accurately compared to smoking and driving because smoking and driving cause maximum danger to human life. As a result of this, nothing seems worth controlling because everything seems to be risk-free. The words closest in meaning to 'as a result' or 'therefore' are 'so' and 'ergo.'

question7.questionText: The demise of the rigorous academic curriculum in high school resulted, in part, from the progressive rhetoric that ______ the study of subjects previously thought inappropriate as part of school learning.
question7.explanation: The word 'previously' suggests that the subjects which were earlier not accepted as part of school learning by the rigid academic curriculum were later recommended by progressive rhetoric, which helped in the demise of the rigid curriculum. The words which closely describe 'recommended' are 'advocated' and 'sanctioned.'

question8.passage: A 'scientistic' view of language was dominant among philosophers and linguists who affected to develop a scientific analysis of human thought and behavior in the early part of this century. Under the force of this view, it was perhaps inevitable that the art of rhetoric should pass from the status of being regarded as of questionable worth (because although it might be both a source of pleasure and a means to urge people to right action, it might also be a means to distort truth and a source of misguided action) to the status of being wholly condemned. If people are regarded only as machines guided by logic, as they were by these 'scientistic' thinkers, rhetoric is likely to be held in low regard; for the most obvious truth about rhetoric is that it speaks to the whole person. It presents its arguments first to the person as a rational being, because persuasive discourse, if honestly conceived, always has a basis in reasoning. Logical argument is the plot, as it were, of any speech or essay that is respectfully intended to persuade people. Yet it is a characterizing feature of rhetoric that it goes beyond this and appeals to the parts of our nature that are involved in feeling, desiring, acting, and suffering. It recalls relevant instances of the emotional reactions of people to circumstances—real or fictional—that are similar to our own circumstances. Such is the purpose of both historical accounts and fables in persuasive discourse: they indicate literally or symbolically how people may react emotionally, with hope or fear, to particular circumstances. A speech attempting to persuade people can achieve little unless it takes into account the aspect of their being related to such hopes and fears.
question8.questionText: It can be inferred from the passage that in the late nineteenth century rhetoric was regarded as
options: the only necessary element of persuasive discourse
a dubious art in at least two ways
an outmoded and tedious amplification of logic
an open offense to the rational mind
the most important of the humanistic studies
correctAnswer: a dubious art in at least two ways
question8.explanation: The answer is (B). In the first paragraph, the passage states that the status of rhetoric changed. Earlier it was considered to be of questionable worth (even though it might be a means to distort truth and a source of misguided action). This implies that rhetoric was regarded as a dubious art in at least two ways—as a means to distort truth and as a source of misguided action.

question9.passage: A 'scientistic' view of language was dominant among philosophers and linguists who affected to develop a scientific analysis of human thought and behavior in the early part of this century. Under the force of this view, it was perhaps inevitable that the art of rhetoric should pass from the status of being regarded as of questionable worth (because although it might be both a source of pleasure and a means to urge people to right action, it might also be a means to distort truth and a source of misguided action) to the status of being wholly condemned.
